author: daniellehrner
content:
There is a lot of discussion on 7702 if in-protocol revocation is needed or not. How do the other client teams think about that? Is it the same as for 3047 that it is a must or not? There is definitely a trade-off to be made between functionality and in-protocol revocation. A clear position on this would help steer the discussion it.

https://ethereum-magicians.org/t/eip-7702-set-eoa-account-code-for-one-transaction/19923/1

author: lightclient
content:
My position is that there should not be in-protocol revocation. It adds undue complexity to the protocol. If we were to do max nonce we also need to open the discussion of how to actually bump the nonce more.

I do think we should have a NONCE opcode so contracts can opt-in to using nonce as a revocation mechanism

author: _shemnon
content: My position is that we should not mutate the EOA to have new catastropic risk exposures that cannot be mitigated.  All EOA signatures evaluated by the protocol have some sort of an "expiration" because they are all over a nonce.  DeFi does other things, but that is all in the EVM layer.  Eternal in-protocol authorizations for an EOA account are a new and significant problem.
